doom.driver: Zelensky tells BBC Putin has started WW3 and must be stopped.
doom.summary: On the four-year anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion, Zelensky told the BBC that Putin has already started World War Three — which is either a desperate plea for Western attention or a sober assessment from the man watching it happen from the front row. Meanwhile, US assets are reportedly positioned for a 'highly kinetic' war with Iran, El Mencho's cartel is burning Mexico to the ground in his memory, and China's leverage just got a quiet boost from the Supreme Court. It's the kind of day where every crisis is loudly competing for the title of Most Likely To Spiral.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: Zelensky invokes WW3 framing on the war's four-year mark while US forces mass in the Middle East for potential 'highly kinetic' conflict with Iran — two simultaneous escalation tracks.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: China's leverage rises ahead of a leaders summit as the Supreme Court's tariff ruling hands Beijing a diplomatic gift and complicates US negotiating posture on Taiwan.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: Sam Altman dismisses AI resource concerns and Trump unveils a 'Tech Corps' to spread American AI globally — the arms race in influence accelerates with minimal guardrails.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: El Mencho's death has unleashed cartel retaliatory violence across a dozen Mexican states, shutting down cities and trapping American tourists — state-level chaos with no clear end point.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: Researchers successfully hid backdoors in 40MB binaries and tested whether AI could find them — a quiet reminder that AI security evaluation remains deeply unsolved.

doom.dalle_prompt: Pixel art, 16-bit SNES style, silhouette composition, Kyiv government quarter at dusk in late winter — the neoclassical cream and ochre facade of a formal government building looms in deep background, its columned portico and wrought-iron fencing dissolved into dark navy shadow, bare chestnut and linden trees lining the boulevard reduced to skeletal black claws against a smoldering orange sky. Heavy concrete blast barriers and sandbag checkpoints form a jagged silhouette line across the foreground, their blocky shapes cutting hard against the threatening amber glow behind. Inside a tall arched window — backlit by the warm island of broadcast soft-box lighting — two seated figures face each other across a long dark conference table, rendered as pure black silhouettes: one leaning forward with clasped hands and intense compact posture, the other slightly reclined with the stillness of a veteran journalist, BBC camera rig and boom microphone silhouetted beside them. Standing silhouettes of security personnel flank the doorway, earpiece cables catching the faintest orange edge-light. Dirty residual snow on cobblestones reflects smoldering orange from the sky. A Ukrainian flag pole silhouette rises in the corner of the room. Dominant palette of deep navy, charcoal, and threatening smoldering orange, heavy shadows consuming the scene, warm light feeling dangerous rather than safe, no text, no antialiasing.

dawn.driver: Winter Olympics 2026 closes after setting 'a new standard for future'. Italy's record medal haul crowns Milano Cortina Winter Olympics as Verona hosts a music-filled farewell.
dawn.blurb: THE WORLD CAME TOGETHER AND MADE IT BEAUTIFUL
dawn.summary: Against a backdrop of war, geopolitical tension, and cartel violence, the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics closed in Verona with a music-filled celebration that officials say set 'a new standard for future' Games. Italy's record medal haul reminded the world that human excellence — athletic, cultural, organizational — still thrives when nations choose cooperation over conflict. The U.S. also finished second in the gold medal tally, with athletes from Alaska to Vermont proving that quiet, unglamorous dedication still produces extraordinary things.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: The Milano Cortina Games closed with a music-filled ceremony in Verona, declared a new standard for Olympic hosting, as athletes from dozens of nations competed without incident.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: An international team of scientists working across borders in Niger discovered an entirely new dinosaur species, Spinosaurus mirabilis, reminding us that collaborative curiosity still drives discovery.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: A newly discovered giant blade-crested spinosaurus unveiled in the Sahara shows that Earth still holds wonders — and that science funded and pursued across nations keeps revealing them.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: Two Colorado utilities are actively pushing back against the Trump administration's order to keep coal plants running, signaling that the clean energy transition has momentum even under political headwinds.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: The bones of St. Francis of Assisi went on rare public display in Italy, drawing pilgrims and tourists alike in a moment of shared reverence that transcended politics and division.

dawn.dalle_prompt: Pixel art, 16-bit SNES style, night scene, no text, no antialiasing. The ancient Verona Arena fills the frame — two-thousand-year-old tiered semicircular walls of weathered amber and ochre stone rising dramatically into a deep navy night sky, every surface washed in sweeping beams of warm golden and teal stage lighting that paint the Roman stonework in radiant theatrical color. Massive glowing video screens embedded against the ancient stone blaze with the final moments of twin Olympic cauldron flames being extinguished simultaneously — one against a city skyline, one against snow-capped Dolomite peaks — casting fading warm orange light across the arena bowl. On the arena floor far below, 1,500 athletes in a mosaic of colorful national team jackets are packed together, arms raised, jumping, confetti explosions in red, blue, green and white cascading down over their heads from above. At center stage a figure in white holds aloft the Olympic flag before outstretched French officials' hands receive it in formal handover. Sweeping color beams — no fireworks, only soft ethereal washes of deep amber and warm teal — arc across the open night sky above the ancient elliptical walls. Deep shadows dominate the stone tiers, interrupted only by the radiant glow of screens, stage rigs, and cascading confetti light.
